subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Office Space (Question No. 918)

p.span: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Office Space
(Question No. 918)
Mr Conroy asked the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, in writing, on 17 August 2015:

In respect of office space leased or owned by the Minister's department(s), (a) where are these offices located, (b) how much space (in square metres) is each office, (c) how much of this space is currently unused, and of this, what is the cost of (i) rent per month, (ii) utilities, including electricity and/or gas, telephone and internet, (iii) office furniture and/or hired equipment, including artwork and plants, and (iv) any other associated services.
Mr Dutton: The answer to the honourable member's question is:
Part (a) and (b) – Please refer to Attachment A.1 and A.2
Part (c) – The Department of Immigration and Border Protection (DIBP) currently has a 19.5% accommodation unused rate for sites in the ACT, and a further 30% across all onshore offices.
Parts (c) (i) (ii) and (iii) (iv) – To answer these questions would be an unreasonable diversion of departmental resources.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Energy Efficiency Upgrades (Question No. 936)

p.span: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Energy Efficiency Upgrades
(Question No. 936)
Mr Conroy asked the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, in writing, on 17 August 2015:

In respect of the Minister's departmental office(s), has the building(s) received energy efficiency upgrades; if so, (a) when, and (b) how has this upgrade affected (i) average energy use, and (ii) average energy cost.
Mr Dutton: The answer to the honourable member's question is:
The Portfolio has not undertaken any energy efficiency upgrades in the last financial year to any of the office buildings.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Consultants (Question No. 954)

p.span: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Consultants
(Question No. 954)
Mr Conroy asked the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, in writing, on 17 August 2015:

In respect of the use of: (a) consultants, and (b) contractors, by the Minister's department(s) in 2014-15, (i) what total sum was spent, (ii) what services were provided, and (iii) which firms provided the services.
Mr Dutton: The answer to the honourable member's question for the Minister's Portfolio is as follows:

span.span: Department of Immigration and Border Protection (DIBP)

p.span: In respect of the use of (a) consultants by DIBP in 2014-15:

(i) The department entered into 59 new consultancy contracts involving total actual expenditure of $23.495 million (inclusive of GST). In addition, 21 ongoing consultancy contracts were active during 2014-15, involving total actual expenditure of $1.623 million (inclusive of GST).
(ii) The consultancy services provided were in relation to:

Information technology, management advisory services, audit services, education and training services, strategic planning, safety and risk analysis, financial modelling, project management, research programs, architectural and building, business intelligence, human resources, refugee programs and procurement.
(iii) The following firms provided the consultancy services:

In respect of the use of (b) contractors by DIBP in 2014-15:
(i) The detailed information sought is not readily available in a consolidated form and it would be an unreasonable diversion of resources to respond.
(ii) Typical services provided by contractors include:

Management advisory, project administration, temporary personnel, information technology, security and access control systems, audit services, advertising, administration, health, education and training, human resources and recruitment, legal and temporary personnel.
(iii) All contracts for the portfolio in excess of $10 000 are reported on the AusTender website, www.tenders.gov.au.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Agriculture and Water Resources: Media Monitoring (Question No. 964)

p.span: Department of Agriculture and Water Resources: Media Monitoring
(Question No. 964)
Mr Conroy asked the Minister for Agriculture and Water Resources, in writing, on 17 August 2015:
What sum was spent by the Minister's department(s) on media monitoring and associated services in 2014-15.
Mr Joyce: The Minister for Agriculture and Water Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
In 2014-15, the Department of Agriculture and Water Resources spent $185,684.19 on media monitoring and associated services, which is $13,434.75 less than the previous financial year.
In 2012-13 the Department of Agriculture spent $208,495.61 on media monitoring and associated services.
In 2011-12 the department of Agriculture spent $207,622.90 on media monitoring and associated services.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Media Monitoring (Question No. 972)

p.span: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Media Monitoring
(Question No. 972)
Mr Conroy asked the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, in writing, on 17 August 2015:
What sum was spent by the Minister's department(s) on media monitoring and associated services in 2014-15.
Mr Dutton: The answer to the honourable member's question is:
In 2014-15, both the Department of Immigration and Border Protection (DIBP) and the Australian Customs and Border Protections Service (ACBPS) contracted iSentia to manage daily media monitoring.

To assist with streamlining financial processes due to the integration of the media sections of DIBP and the ACBPS, it was agreed upon that the iSentia related expenditure for the 2014-15 financial year would be split between the two agencies.
ACBPS met the costs for both contracts for the first two quarters (01/07/2014-31/12/2014) and DIBP covered the costs for the last two quarters (01/01/2015-30/06/2015).
(a) The value of the ACBPS iSentia contract for 2014-15 - $117,672.17
(b) The value of the DIBP iSentia contract for 2014-15 - $ 221,455.28
Monitoring costs depend on the number of media clips delivered per period.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Market Research (Question No. 990)

p.span: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Market Research
(Question No. 990)
Mr Conroy asked the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, in writing, on 17 August 2015:
What sum was spent by the Minister's department(s) on market research and associated services in 2014-15, and what policy areas did this inform.
Mr Dutton: The answer to the honourable member's question is:

During 2014–15, the Australian Customs and Border Protection Services spent the following on market research and associated services for the anti-people smuggling communication campaign that informed the Operation Sovereign Borders policy to stop the boats, prevent people risking their lives at sea in the hands of criminals and preserve the integrity of Australia's borders.
Market Research – GST Inclusive
Total amount paid
Red Elephant Research
Total (GST inclusive)
Market Research – GST Not Applicable
Total amount paid
International Organisation for Migration Vietnam - Bangladesh
Total (GST not applicable)
During 2014–15, the Department of Immigration and Border Protection spent the following on market research and associated services:
Market Research – GST Inclusive
Total amount paid
McNair Ingenuity Research Pty Ltd: Tracking and evaluation market research for the No way campaign

- The advertising and research associated with the No way campaign informed the Operation Sovereign Borders policy to stop the boats, prevent people risking their lives at sea in the hands of criminals and preserve the integrity of Australia's borders. This research supported Strategic Policy and Planning and Immigration and Citizenship Policy.
Hall & Partners Open Mind Pty Ltd: Research for the Customs Watch programme
- The Customs Watch research informed the rebranding of the Customs Watch programme and associated communication strategy.
Cubit Media Research Pty Ltd: Large scale collation and comparative analysis of media representations of migration

- This quantitative research involved the collation and comparative analysis of print and online media representations of migration across several countries, including in relation to thematic content and tone. It provided insights into how migration issues are contextualised and reported by various countries' media, including for informing future information and communication campaigns. This research supported Migration Policy.
Hall & Partners Open Mind Pty Ltd: Illegal work tracking market research

- Associated with the Employer Awareness of Illegal Workers campaign activity conducted in 2012-13/2013-14. The objective is to track employers' awareness of illegal work practices and the steps they can take to ensure they do not employ illegal workers. This research supported Compliance Policy.
Total – GST Inclusive

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Advertising (Question No. 1008)

p.span: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Advertising
(Question No. 1008)
Mr Conroy asked the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, in writing, on 17 August 2015:
What sum was spent by the Minister's department(s) on advertising and associated services in 2014-15, and what policy areas did this relate to.
Mr Dutton: The answer to the honourable member's question is:
During 2014–15, the Department of Immigration and Border Protection spent the following on advertising and associated services:
Advertising – GST Inclusive
Total amount paid
Mitchell & Partners Australia Pty Ltd: No way campaign advertising – phase 1

- The advertising and research associated with the No way campaign informed the Operation Sovereign Borders policy to stop the boats, prevent people risking their lives at sea in the hands of criminals and preserve the integrity of Australia's borders. This activity supported Strategic Policy and Planning and Immigration and Citizenship Policy.
Mitchell & Partners Australia Pty Ltd: No way campaign advertising - phase 2

- The advertising and research associated with the No way campaign informed the Operation Sovereign Borders policy to stop the boats, prevent people risking their lives at sea in the hands of criminals and preserve the integrity of Australia's borders. This activity supported Strategic Policy and Planning and Immigration and Citizenship Policy.
Mitchell & Partners Australia Pty Ltd: Community Status Resolution Service advertising for visa overstayers

- Promoted the Department's Community Status Resolution Service (CSRS) encouraged unlawful non-citizens to engage with the Department to resolve their immigration status. This activity supported Compliance and Status Resolution Policy.
Mitchell & Partners Australia Pty Ltd: Onshore voluntary returns campaign advertising illegal maritime arrivals
- Supported the promotion of assisted voluntary returns as an option for illegal maritime arrivals. This activity supported Onshore Protection Policy and Compliance and Status Resolution Policy.
The Trustee for LMG Melbourne Unit Trust: Community engagement services - No way campaign

- The advertising and research associated with the No way campaign informed the Operation Sovereign Borders policy to stop the boats, prevent people risking their lives at sea in the hands of criminals and preserve the integrity of Australia's borders. This activity supported Strategic Policy and Planning and Immigration and Citizenship Policy.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Office Equipment (Question No. 1026)

p.span: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Office Equipment
(Question No. 1026)
Mr Conroy asked the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, in writing, on 17 August 2015:

What sum did the Minister's department spend in 2014-15 on the purchase and/or lease of (a) food and beverage equipment, and (b) exercise equipment, for staff in the (i) Minister's office, and (ii) departmental office(s).
Mr Dutton: The answer to the honourable member's question is:
(a) (i) Departmental records indicate that there was no purchase and/or lease of food and beverage equipment in the Minister's office during 2014-15.
(ii) To answer this question would be an unreasonable diversion of departmental resources.
(b) (i) Departmental records indicate that there was no purchase and/or lease of exercise equipment in the Minister's office during 2014-15.
(ii) The Minister's departments spent $40,861 on the purchase and/or lease of exercise equipment for staff in departmental offices in 2014-15.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Conferences (Question No. 1392)

p.span: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Conferences
(Question No. 1392)
Mr Conroy asked the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, in writing, on 17 August 2015.

Did the Minister's department host any conferences in 2014-15; if so (a) on what date(s) did each conference occur, and at what location(s), (b) what total sum was spent on each conference, and of this, what sum was spent on (i) meals and accommodation, and what are the details, (ii) travel, and what are the details, and (iii) social events, and what are the details, (iv) travel, and what are the details, and (c) what outcomes were achieved at each conference.
Mr Dutton: The answer to the honourable member's question is:

Information is not maintained on conferences hosted by the department. An official hospitality register is maintained, but conferences are not captured in this register. The provision of food and drink in relation to conferences comes within the definition of 'Business Catering' which does not constitutes official hospitality under the Department's Accountable Authority Instructions. Additionally, there are no specific general ledger codes specifically for 'conferences' nor is travel information linked to business catering costs.

Mr Dutton: The answer to the honourable member's question is:
The department does not record or hold information about what conferences the Minister hosted in 2014-15.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Ministerial Hospitality (Question No. 1474)

p.span: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Ministerial Hospitality
(Question No. 1474)
Mr Conroy asked the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, in writing, on 17 August 2015:

In respect of catering and hospitality by the Minister in 2014-15, (a) what total sum was spent,(b) for what functions was the catering and hospitality, (c) on what date(s) did each function occur, and at what location(s), and (d) for each function, what sum was spent on (i) meals, (ii) drinks, (iii) hospitality staff, and (iv) other costs.
Mr Dutton: The answer to the honourable member's question is:
For the period 1 July 2014 to 22 December 2014, the total sum spent by the former Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, in respect of catering and hospitality was nil.
For the period 23 December 2014 to 30 June 2015, my expenditure in respect of catering and hospitality was $1,665.75.
In February 2015, I travelled to Papua New Guinea (PNG) to meet with the

PNG Minister for Foreign Affairs and Immigration. I hosted a dinner following this meeting. The cost of this function was AUD $571.33. A further break down of these costs is not available as the department does not keep records down to this level of detail.
In May 2015, I travelled to Sri Lanka to meet the Sri Lankan Prime Minister and other key Ministers. I hosted a dinner following this meeting. The cost of this function was
AUD $1094.42. A further break down of these costs is not available as the department does not keep records down to this level of detail.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Asylum Seekers (Question No. 1493)

p.span: Department of Immigration and Border Protection: Asylum Seekers
(Question No. 1493)
Ms Parke asked the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, in writing, on 7 September 2015:

(1) Why have no refugees been resettled to or integrated in Papua New Guinea (PNG) under the regional resettlement arrangement between Australia and PNG, and has the Australian Government approached the PNG Government about this; if so, what was the response.

(2) Why is the PNG Government restricting the freedom of movement of at least seven refugees, and preventing them from obtaining employment, despite having issued them with work and identity documents, and has the Australian Government made any representations on behalf of these refugees; if not, why not.

(3) Will the Australian Government urge the PNG Government to allow journalists and human rights groups such as Human Rights Watch and the Human Rights Law Centre, access to the detention centre on Manus Island; if not, why not.
Mr Dutton: The answer to the honourable member's question is:

(1) Former PM Rudd signed the PNG Regional Resettlement Arrangement on 19 July 2013 with PNG PM O'Neill. The Coalition has consistently highlighted the serious challenges involved in implementing this deal, in which resettlement was a blank sheet of paper sweetened with $420 million of taxpayers money. The Coalition is working with PNG to implement resettlement and resolve the deficiencies in the arrangement we inherited from Labor.

(2) The Government of PNG has indicated that broader settlement in PNG will not occur until the NEC endorses the National Refugee Policy. Refugees residing at the East Lorengau Refugee Transit Centre are permitted to engage in volunteer work in Manus Province. The Australian Government continues to encourage the Government of PNG to endorse the Policy and commence broader settlement in PNG.

(3) The Manus Regional Processing Centre is managed and administered by the Government of PNG. Decisions regarding access to the Centre therefore rest with the Government of PNG. Organisations including the International Committee for the Red Cross and the Commonwealth Ombudsman make regular visits to the Manus Regional Processing Centre to inspect facilities and report on issues.
